sect1.title: Installing Spring Actionscript
sect1.para: To start using Spring Actionscript in your project you will need to download either the all-in-one swc or the archive with all of the separate extensions:

literal.xlink:title: Spring Actionscript v2.0 Core Package including dependencies

sect1.para: If you want to use the Flex specific functionality you will need to additionally download this .swc as well:
One you've downloaded them place them in your project's library path. In a Flashbuilder project, for instance, this simply means you need to copy them into your 'libs' folder.

sect1.title: Creating an Application Context
sect1.para: The main entry point for the Spring Actionscript library is the application context. There are a number of different context flavours, but for now we'll use the MXMLApplicationContext as this is probably the most commonly used one.
Obviously the MXMLApplicationContext can only be used in a Flex based application, in a pure actionscript environment you can choose any of the other availabe 'Configuration types'.
To create an instance of the MXMLApplicationContext simply add it as an MXML component to your application.
Now, this in itself won't do much of course. We need to tell the application context where to find it's configuration and make sure we know when it has finished loading them.
Let's add a few properties to the context declaration:
In the section we take a look at how we create a configuration file for our MXMLApplicationContext.

sect1.title: Creating a configuration for the MXMLApplicationContext
sect1.para: A configuration file for an MXMLApplicationContext is just a regular MXML component which can be created using the File->New->MXML Component menu.
Choose SASObjects for the MXML component type, call it ObjectsConfiguration and you will get an empty component like this:

The SASObjects component can contain children of type Object which are components that represent so called Object Definitions. These definitions act as a sort of recipe for an object's instantiation and configuration. Let's say we want a presentation model to be managed by the application context. We add a definition for it like this:<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <sas:SASObjects xmlns:fx="http://ns.adobe.com/mxml/2009" xmlns:s="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/spark" xmlns:mx="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/mx" xmlns:sas="http://www.springactionscript.org/mxml/config"> <fx:Script> <![CDATA[ import my.classes.presentationmodels.MainPresentationModel; ]]> </fx:Script> <fx:Declarations> <sas:Object clazz="{MainPresentationModel}" id="mainModel"/> <fx:Declarations> </sas:SASObjects>

Now, to enable the application context to actually create an instance of the MainPresentationModel class it'll be necessary to start the context and let it notify us when it's ready.<fx:Declarations> <sas:MXMLApplicationContext id="MXMLContext" configurations="{[ObjectsConfiguration]}" autoLoad="true" complete="{onComplete(event)}"/> </fx:Declarations>
<fx:Script> <![CDATA[ private function onComplete(event:Event):void { var presentationModel:MainPresentationModel = MXMLContext.getObject('mainModel'); } ]]> </fx:Script>

Spring Actionscript just needs an extra bit of configuration to make sure that MXML (and any other stage) components will be injected, by default this functionality is turned off, but its easy to turn on. You need to add one custom object definition to the configuration:<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <sas:SASObjects xmlns:fx="http://ns.adobe.com/mxml/2009" xmlns:s="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/spark" xmlns:mx="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/mx" xmlns:sas="http://www.springactionscript.org/mxml/config"> <fx:Script> <![CDATA[ import my.classes.presentationmodels.MainPresentationModel; ]]> </fx:Script> <fx:Declarations> <sas:StageAutowireProcessor/>
<sas:Object clazz="{MainPresentationModel}" id="mainModel"/> </fx:Declarations> </sas:SASObjects>And that's it, now after the view component has been aded to the stage it will be injected with the presentation model instance created by the application context.

However, the presentation model might have some dependencies of its own that you would like to configure. For instance, it might have a dependency on an IMainService implementation. Just add the service to the configuration and let the application context inject it into a specified property of the presentationmodel.<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <sas:SASObjects xmlns:fx="http://ns.adobe.com/mxml/2009" xmlns:s="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/spark" xmlns:mx="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/mx" xmlns:sas="http://www.springactionscript.org/mxml/config"> <fx:Script> <![CDATA[ import my.classes.presentationmodels.MainPresentationModel; import my.classes.services.MainService; ]]> </fx:Script> <fx:Declarations> <sas:StageAutowireProcessor/>
<sas:Object clazz="{MainService}" id="mainService"/>
<sas:Object clazz="{MainPresentationModel}" id="mainModel"> <sas:Property name="service" ref="{mainService}"/> </sas:Object> </fx:Declarations> </sas:SASObjects>What if the presentation model wants to initialize itself after each of its dependencies have been satisfied? Use the initMethod property on the object definition for that:
If the method actually needs some arguments, then use the method invocation markup.
sect1.programlisting: <sas:Object clazz="{MainPresentationModel}" id="mainModel"> <sas:Property name="service" ref="{mainService}"/> <sas:MethodInvocation name="initModel"> <sas:Arg value="myStringValue"/> </sas:MethodInvocation> </sas:Object>
sect1.para: By default objects are considered to be singletons when they are managed by the application context, which means only one instance of them is ever created. Each subsequent call to the get Object() method will just return the same instance. If this is not desired the scope of the object definition might be set to prototype.

When an object doesn't need any particular configuration, but just needs to be accesible as a singleton to the application context it may be directly declared in the MXML configuration. For instance, a remote object might be declared like this:<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <sas:SASObjects xmlns:fx="http://ns.adobe.com/mxml/2009" xmlns:s="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/spark" xmlns:mx="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/mx" xmlns:sas="http://www.springactionscript.org/mxml/config"> <fx:Script> <![CDATA[ import my.classes.presentationmodels.MainPresentationModel; import my.classes.services.MainService; ]]> </fx:Script> <fx:Declarations> <mx:RemoteObject id="remoteObject"/>
<sas:StageAutowireProcessor/>
<sas:Object clazz="{MainService}" id="mainService"> <sas:Property name="remoteObject" ref="remoteObject"/> </sas:Object>
<sas:Object clazz="{MainPresentationModel}" id="mainModel"> <sas:Property name="service" ref="{mainService}"/> </sas:Object> </fx:Declarations> </sas:SASObjects>The RemoteObject instance will be added to the application context cache as well, so it may be retrieved from the context by name:var ro:RemoteObject = MXMLContext.getObject('remoteObject');In the same way actionscript properties may be added to the MXML configuration as well, they work in the same way as their MXML versions.<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <sas:SASObjects xmlns:fx="http://ns.adobe.com/mxml/2009" xmlns:s="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/spark" xmlns:mx="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/mx" xmlns:sas="http://www.springactionscript.org/mxml/config"> <fx:Script> <![CDATA[ import my.classes.presentationmodels.MainPresentationModel; import my.classes.services.MainService;
public var collection:ArrayCollection = new ArrayCollection(["myValue1","myValue2","myValue3"]); ]]> </fx:Script> <fx:Declarations> <mx:RemoteObject id="remoteObject"/>
<sas:StageAutowireProcessor/>
<sas:Object clazz="{MainService}" id="mainService"> <sas:Property name="remoteObject" ref="remoteObject"/> </sas:Object>
<sas:Object clazz="{MainPresentationModel}" id="mainModel"> <sas:Property name="service" ref="{mainService}"/> <sas:Property name="list" ref="collection"/> </sas:Object> </fx:Declarations> </sas:SASObjects>

The next step is to let objects communicate with each other using events. To inform Spring Actionscript about which objects dispatch which events and which objects handle those events there are a number of configuration extensions.

Here's how to configure an event dispatcher, let's imagine that the presentation model dispatches CustomEvents called initialized and changed:<sas:Object clazz="{MainPresentationModel}" id="mainModel"> <sas:Property name="service" ref="{mainService}"/> <sas:Property name="list" ref="collection"/> <sas:EventRouterConfiguration eventNames="{CustomEvent.INITIALIZED},{CustomEvent.CHANGED}"/> </sas:Object>

To configure the object that listens for these events, let's say there is an ApplicationManager class that has two methods called initializedHandler() and changedHandler():<sas:Object clazz="{ApplicationManager}" id="applicationManager"> <sas:EventHandlerConfiguration eventName="{CustomEvent.INITIALIZED}" name="initializedHandler"/> <sas:EventHandlerConfiguration eventName="{CustomEvent.CHANGED}" name="changedHandler"/> </sas:Object>
To learn more about event configuration, head on over to the Eventbus integration section.

These are the basic pieces of functionality of the object configuration in Spring Actionscript. A more in-depth look at all of the MXML configuration possibilities is available in the 'MXML Configuration' section.

note.para: To find out more about object definitions, check out the section 'Object Definitions'
To find out more about the different kinds of configuration, check out the section 'Configuration types'
